thread.title: TMC Insider: Mustangs soccer teams make their marks
thread.title_full: TMC Insider: Mustangs soccer teams make their marks

author: Signal Staff
title: TMC Insider: Mustangs soccer teams make their marks
text:
TMC Insider: Mustangs soccer teams make their marks Men's, women's squads snag signature wins against Vanguard Posted: October 12, 2015 8:15 p.m. Updated: October 12, 2015 8:15 p.m. The Master’s College women’s soccer player Tara Struiksma (11) heads the ball away from a Vanguard defender as TMC’s Tara Aalem (19) looks on at TMC on Saturday. Photo by Dhon Wellons/TMC Sports Information 
Both soccer teams for The Master’s College bagged signature wins over Vanguard University, while Mustang volleyball beat Hope International and Concordia (Mich.) in a pair of 3-1 victories. 
Men’s Soccer 
It was only fitting in a much-hyped match featuring two of the NAIA’s Top 25 clubs that one of the nation’s best players would make the difference. 
That’s exactly what Humphrey Mahowa did. The TMC sophomore striker and last year’s Golden State Athletic Conference Player of the Year scored the winning goal 3:05 into overtime to lift the 17th-ranked Mustangs past No. 3 Vanguard, 2-1, Saturday afternoon on Reese Field. 
The dramatic win avenged a 2-0 loss at Vanguard on Sept. 23 and improved the Mustangs to 9-3-1 overall and 3-2 in the GSAC, where they sit tied with Westmont and San Diego Christian for third place (nine points). 
Mahowa’s conference-leading 10th goal of the 2015 campaign was made possible by some terrific Mustang defense, as goalie Casey Phillips made a save 1:53 into the extra stanza and his fellow defenders teamed for a block before the ball was turned back up the field. 
Once the ball got across midfield, Benjamin Tembo and Mahowa went two-on-two against the Lion defenders and Tembo found his teammate, who put the ball past Vanguard’s Brandon Gomez at the 93:05 mark for the golden goal. 
Commenting on Tembo’s assist, Rickard said, “Benji has been really stellar the past three games and his skill produced the chance that Humphrey finished.” 
The Mustangs got to overtime because Zach Klindworth scored off a Christopher Logan assist with in the 77th minute in regulation to tie the game. It was Klindworth’s third goal of the season. 
This week, TMC hits the road to face new GSAC member Menlo on Thursday and at William Jessup two days later. 
Women’s Soccer 
If TMC team was looking for a signature moment for its 2015 campaign, it found it Saturday afternoon. 
With just eight seconds left in double overtime and the score knotted at 0-0, Tara Struiksma faced off against Vanguard’s goalkeeper Kaycee Smith. A penalty kick had been awarded to the Mustangs after freshman Lynnae George was brought to the ground by an aggressive foul from the Lions defense. 
Struiksma had yet to score a goal this season entering into Saturday’s match, but she bested Smith for the win, subsequently sending the Lady Mustangs’ bench into a frenzy. 
The 22nd-ranked Lady Mustangs (6-6-1, 3-2 GSAC) upended the 12th-ranked Lions (9-2, 6-3) for TMC’s sixth victory of the season. Notably, Saturday’s win keeps the Mustangs undefeated on their home turf. 
Looking to build off Saturday’s impressive win, the Mustangs now prepare for a pair of away matches against Menlo College on Thursday and William Jessup on Saturday. 
Women’s Volleyball 
TMC got back to its winning ways last week by beating Hope International in four sets (25-23, 25-22, 19-25, 25-15) on Tuesday in Fullerton and non-conference opponent Concordia (Mich.) to the tune of 3-1 (25-23, 25-12, 23-25, 25-17) on Friday at Bross Court. 
With the wins, TMC’s 2015 record improved to 13-8 and 5-3 in conference play. 
Tonight, the Mustangs will continue their GSAC hiatus by taking on West Coast Baptist at 7 p.m. 
For more information about The Master’s College Athletic Department, visit www.masters.edu/athletics, or follow the Mustangs on Facebook at Facebook.com/TMCAthletics and Twitter and Instagram at @TMCAthletics.
